displayName.text: John Jay College of Criminal Justice

formattedAddress: 524 W 59th St, New York, NY 10019, USA
adrFormatAddress: 524 W 59th St, New York, NY 10019, USA

originalText.text: Great 4 year college!! Has very great majors and minors! Great institution for those who wants to get in the Criminal Justice field or in law and so forth!! It's a big college that pretty much has all fun stuff!! Great to make friends and dating relationships,and so forth!

text.text: Great 4 year college!! Has very great majors and minors! Great institution for those who wants to get in the Criminal Justice field or in law and so forth!! It's a big college that pretty much has all fun stuff!! Great to make friends and dating relationships,and so forth!

originalText.text: Really beautiful college with modern facilities. The buildings are all connected and the campus and neighborhood is relatively safe.

text.text: Really beautiful college with modern facilities. The buildings are all connected and the campus and neighborhood is relatively safe.

originalText.text: The best criminal justice university nationwide, and I’m glad to be a part of it. So many great activities and helpful resources for the future. By the way, don’t forget to visit the cafeteria for a delicious meal.

text.text: The best criminal justice university nationwide, and I’m glad to be a part of it. So many great activities and helpful resources for the future. By the way, don’t forget to visit the cafeteria for a delicious meal.

originalText.text: Very nice school. I’m currently enrolled here as a first year and it has been a blast going to class. The school is huge and everything is so beautiful and the architecture is so interesting. The dining hall serves really good food and the school is so clean. The classrooms are so big and all the professor are so nice and helpful. The lounge is wonderful and there are plenty of places for you to stay as you wait for your next class.

text.text: Very nice school. I’m currently enrolled here as a first year and it has been a blast going to class. The school is huge and everything is so beautiful and the architecture is so interesting. The dining hall serves really good food and the school is so clean. The classrooms are so big and all the professor are so nice and helpful. The lounge is wonderful and there are plenty of places for you to stay as you wait for your next class.

originalText.text: John Jay is just another example of how horrible the CUNY system really is. Doesn’t matter if it’s their 2 year schools and or 4 yr - CUNY really highlights the farce that “higher education” is. Underfunded(thanks Adams), unprofessional and of course under paid staff who can barely manage to pretend to care, ancient and/or mediocre facilities - the list goes on. It’s sad on many levels. Most families in NYC can’t afford the private colleges and these public schools which dangle low costs like a carrot are for a lot of people their only option. But once you actually attend a CUNY school you quickly realize that learning via YouTube is actually a better option in any and all cases. The decline of education in the US is palpable after a single semester - I immediately asked myself what the point was. It’s not worth it despite it being cheaper than private schools. The time, the energy, the money - the internships are garbage. If you’re an upperclassmen and you get any emails regarding a “Micro Internship” immediately delete it - the program is total garbage the “employers”are fake and/or total fledglings who don’t know what they’re doing. Some classes are ok with the right Professor but that in and of itself is a coin flip. I had an intro to computer science professor straight up tell the class that if you’re having trouble with any of the material in his course you should just give up. Brilliant. Stay away from CUNY. If you can’t afford private just go online - college will barely be a thing in 20 years. CUNY makes its living off the ignorant and poor - most cuny students have no idea that the programs they’re in are in no way preparing them for real life and won’t know until it’s too late.
